Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: The packaging of intellectual positions and views is one of the most active enterprises of some of the best minds of our day. The viewer of television, the listener to radio, the reader of magazines, is presented with a whole complex of elements—all the way from ingenious rhetoric to carefully selected data and statistics—to make it easy for him to “make up his own mind” with the minimum of difficulty and effort.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Enlightenment is achieved only when, in addition to knowing what an author says, you know what he means and why he says it.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: The art of reading, in short, includes all of the same skills that are involved in the art of unaided discovery: keenness of observation, readily available memory, range of imagination, and, of course, an intellect trained in analysis and reflection.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: you ask a living teacher a question, he will probably answer you. If you are puzzled by what he says, you can save yourself the trouble of thinking by asking him what he means. If, however, you ask a book a question, you must answer it yourself.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: a book is like nature or the world. When you question it, it answers you only to the extent that you do the work of thinking and analysis yourself.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Still another name for this level might be skimming or pre-reading. However, we do not mean the kind of skimming that is characterized by casual or random browsing through a book. Inspectional reading is the art of skimming systematically.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Analytical reading is thorough reading, complete reading, or good reading—the best reading you can do. If inspectional reading is the best and most complete reading that is possible given a limited time, then analytical reading is the best and most complete reading that is possible given unlimited time.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Francis Bacon once remarked that “some books are to be tasted, others to be swallowed, and some few to be chewed and digested.” Reading a book analytically is chewing and digesting it.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Another name for this level might be comparative reading. When reading syntopically, the reader reads many books, not just one, and places them in relation to one another and to a subject about which they all revolve.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Let it suffice for the moment to say that syntopical reading is not an easy art, and that the rules for it are not widely known. Nevertheless, syntopical reading is probably the most rewarding of all reading activities. The benefits are so great that it is well worth the trouble of learning how to do it.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: The child who is not yet ready to read is frustrated if attempts are made to teach him, and he may carry over his dislike for the experience into his later school career and even into adult life. Delaying the beginning of reading instruction beyond the reading readiness stage is not nearly so serious, despite the feelings of parents who may fear that their child is “backward” or is not “keeping up” with his peers.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Only when he has mastered all of the four stages of elementary reading is the child prepared to move on to the higher levels of reading. Only then can he read independently and learn on his own. Only then can he begin to become a really good reader.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Of course, if the blurb is nothing but a puff for the book, you will ordinarily be able to discover this at a glance. But that in itself can tell you something about the work. Perhaps the book does not say anything of importance—and that is why the blurb does not say anything, either.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: In tackling a difficult book for the first time, read it through without ever stopping to look up or ponder the things you do not understand right away.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Many books are hardly worth even skimming; some should be read quickly; and a few should be read at a rate, usually quite slow, that allows for complete comprehension. It is wasteful to read a book slowly that deserves only a fast reading; speed reading skills can help you solve that problem.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Every book should be read no more slowly than it deserves, and no more quickly than you can read it with satisfaction and comprehension.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Good books, fiction or nonfiction, deserve such reading. To use a good book as a sedative is conspicuous waste. To fall asleep or, what is the same, to let your mind wander during the hours you planned to devote to reading for profit—that is, primarily for understanding—is clearly to defeat your own ends.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: 1. WHAT IS THE BOOK ABOUT AS A WHOLE?

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: 2. WHAT IS BEING SAID IN DETAIL, AND HOW?

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Good books are over your head; they would not be good for you if they were not. And books that are over your head weary you unless you can reach up to them and pull yourself up to their level.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: Any art or skill is possessed by those who have formed the habit of operating according to its rules. This is the way the artist or craftsman in any field differs from those who lack his skill.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: A practical book will soon betray its character by the frequent occurrence of such words as “should” and “ought,” “good” and “bad,” “ends” and “means.”

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: History is chronotopic. Chronos is the Greek word for time, topos the Greek word for place.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: A book comes to you with flesh on its bare bones and clothes over its flesh. It is all dressed up. You do not have to undress it or tear the flesh off its limbs to get at the firm structure that underlies the soft surface. But you must read the book with X-ray eyes, for it is an essential part of your apprehension of any book to grasp its structure.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: RULE 2. STATE THE UNITY OF THE WHOLE BOOK IN A SINGLE SENTENCE, OR AT MOST A FEW SENTENCES (A SHORT PARAGRAPH).

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: RULE 3. SET FORTH THE MAJOR PARTS OF THE BOOK, AND SHOW HOW THESE ARE ORGANIZED INTO A WHOLE, BY BEING ORDERED TO ONE ANOTHER AND TO THE UNITY OF THE WHOLE.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: You have not grasped a complex unity if all you know about it is how it is one. You must also know how it is many, not a many that consists of a lot of separate things, but an organized many.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: The flesh of a book is as much a part of it as the skeleton. This is as true of books as it is of animals and human beings. The flesh—the outline spelled out, “read out,” as we sometimes say—adds an essential dimension.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: The person who says of a novel that he has “read enough to get the idea” does not know what he is talking about. He cannot be correct, for if the novel is any good at all, the idea is in the whole and cannot be found short of reading the whole.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: You should be able to state the main question that the book tries to answer, and you should be able to state the subordinate questions if the main question is complex and has many parts. You should not only have a fairly adequate grasp of all the questions involved but should also be able to put the questions in an intelligible order.

Title: How to Read a Book
Author: Charles Van Doren and Mortimer J. Adler
Highlight Text: We want to emphasize, however, that we do not mean for you to fall into what is called by critics the intentional fallacy. That is the fallacy of thinking you can discover what was in an author’s mind from the book he has written.

Title: Consider Phlebas (A Culture Novel Book 1)

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: Although fungi have long been lumped together with plants, they are actually more closely related to animals—an example of the kind of category mistake that researchers regularly make in their struggle to understand fungal lives.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: Our perceptions work in large part by expectation. It takes less cognitive effort to make sense of the world using preconceived images updated with a small amount of new sensory information than to constantly form entirely new perceptions from scratch. It is our preconceptions that create the blind spots in which magicians do their work.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: Tricked out of our expectations, we fall back on our senses. What’s astonishing is the gulf between what we expect to find and what we find when we actually look.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: IN HUMAN HISTORY, truffles have long been associated with sex. The word for truffle in many languages translates to “testicle,” as in the old Castilian turmas de tierra, or Earth’s testicles.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: “Truffles bring out the dark side of people. It’s like money lying on the ground, but it’s perishable and mercurial.”

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: Sex happens when a - hypha attracts and fuses with a + hypha. One partner plays a paternal role, providing genetic material only. The other plays a maternal role, providing genetic material and growing the flesh that matures into truffles and spores. Truffles differ from humans in that either + or - mating types can be maternal or paternal—it is as if all humans were both male and female and equally able to play the part of a mother or a father, provided we could have sex with a partner of the opposite mating type.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: When we humanize the world, we may prevent ourselves from understanding the lives of other organisms on their own terms.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: Mycelium is ecological connective tissue, the living seam by which much of the world is stitched into relation.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: One study estimated that if a hypha was as wide as a human hand, it would be able to lift an eight-ton school bus.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: “We commonly think of animals and plants as matter, but they are really systems through which matter is continually passing.” When we see an organism, from a fungus to a pine tree, we catch a single moment in its continual development.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: The researchers wondered whether, if they trained a flatworm to remember features of its environment and then cut off its head, it would retain the memory when it has grown a new head and brain. Remarkably, the answer is yes. The flatworms’ memory appeared to reside in a part of their body outside the brain.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: When lichens die and decompose, they give rise to the first soils in new ecosystems. Lichens are how the inanimate mineral mass within rocks is able to cross over into the metabolic cycles of the living.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: Lichens are cosmopolitan bodies, a place where lives meet. A fungus can’t photosynthesize by itself, but by partnering with an alga or photosynthetic bacterium it can acquire this ability horizontally. Similarly, an alga or photosynthetic bacterium can’t grow tough layers of protective tissue or digest rock, but by partnering with a fungus it gains access to these capabilities—suddenly. Together, these taxonomically remote organisms build composite life-forms capable of entirely new possibilities. By comparison with plant cells that can’t be parted from their chloroplasts, lichens’ relationships are open.

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: The authors of a seminal paper on the symbiotic view of life take a clear stance on this point. “There have never been individuals,” they declare. “We are all lichens.”

Title: Entangled Life: How Fungi Make Our Worlds, Change Our Minds & Shape Our Futures
Author: Merlin Sheldrake
Highlight Text: And yet the absence of evidence does not provide evidence of absence.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: The image is a declaration of pure bliss with the clear message that happiness is attainable, and the path to that place requires no more than an uninhibited persona, hip music, and an unlimited supply of drugs.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: Life is not a snapshot. It’s a real-time streaming video— and the video plays on, whether we affect it or not.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: I knew immediately that the rest of my life operated in the same way, as a collection of separate and independent processes, each one functioning in reliable 1-2-3-4 sequence according to its own construction.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: there is no human King of Everything who directs the goings-on of the world. On its own and no matter what, this earth keeps turning and life carries on in an overall structured and organized pattern, and . . . no one here on earth is in charge!

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: The incontrovertible laws of nature cause the mechanics of the world to be dependable and predictable, and the God-given gift with which we humans have been blessed is the ability to get in the middle of those mechanics, to manipulate them, to direct our lives to be what we want them to be, to use the infallible laws of nature to our advantage.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: Get that your life is already a collection of systems. These life-systems have determined your life condition in this moment, whether your life is going well or not; whether you have managed those systems or not! Systems really do compose life itself! Now your job is to manage them: to fix the broken ones, to discard the ones that are dragging you down, and yes, to introduce some new ones. Don’t say, “I never had systems in my life and that is why I have failed.” Rather, say, “I’ve been failing because I have not been managing my systems, the systems that have been there all along.”

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: We should never be complacent about our connection to the world around us; never underestimate the tenuous grip we have on our individual existences. We must handle our bodies and minds with care. We should be careful about upkeep and maintenance, yet challenge them so they stay strong.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: The base fact of life is this: every single life-result is preceded by a sequence of steps executing over time. Here’s the simple formula: 1→2→3→4 = Result.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: Therefore, the secret to “getting what one wants” lies in spending the majority of one’s efforts in managing the left-hand side of the equation, the 1→2→3→4 part. The painful truth? Most people never see the left-hand side of the formula. Instead, they expend their energies on the right-hand side—the Results segment—endlessly shuffling, reorganizing, and repairing the random bad results created by those unseen and therefore unmanaged systems on the left-hand side.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter
Highlight Text: unmanaged systems produce random results, and random results always add up to chaos.

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)
Author: Sam Carpenter

Author: Sam Carpenter

Author: Sam Carpenter

Author: Sam Carpenter

Title: Work the System: The Simple Mechanics of Making More and Working Less (4th Edition)

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: The older I get the more I hold each day precious. I’ve become steadily more relentless in purging from my life things, activities and people who no longer add value while seeking out and adding those that do.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: If you intend to achieve financial freedom, you are going to have to think differently. It starts by recognizing that debt should not be considered normal. It should be recognized as the vicious, pernicious destroyer of wealth-building potential it truly is. It has no place in your financial life.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: Waste no time. Debt is a crisis that needs immediate attention. If you are currently in debt, paying it off is your top priority. Nothing else is more important.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: Stop thinking about what your money can buy. Start thinking about what your money can earn. And then think about what the money it earns can earn.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: “Should I wait until the market has bottomed out and then invest?” This is all about fear and greed, the two major emotions that drive investors.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: The market always recovers. Always. And, if someday it really doesn’t, no investment will be safe and none of this financial stuff will matter anyway.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: Safety is a bit of an illusion. There is no risk-free investment. Once you begin to accumulate wealth, risk is a fact of life.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: Before you start trying to pick individual stocks and/or fund managers ask yourself this simple question: “Am I Warren Buffett?” If the answer is “no,” keep your feet firmly on the ground with indexing.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: Bonds are in our portfolio to provide a deflation hedge. Deflation is one of the two big macro risks to your money. Inflation is the other and we hedge against that with our stocks.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: The two key elements of bonds are the interest rate and the term. The interest rate is simply what the bond issuer (the borrower) has agreed to pay the bond buyer (the lender—you, or by extension the fund you own). The term is simply the length of time the money is being lent.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: When interest rates rise, bond prices fall. When interest rates fall, bond prices rise. In either case, if you hold a bond to the end of its term you will, barring default, get exactly what you paid for it.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: The great irony of investing is that the more you watch and fiddle with your holdings the less well you are likely to do. Fill your basket, add as much as you can along the way and ignore it the rest of the time. You’ll likely wake up rich.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: A portfolio of 100% stocks—which is what VTSAX gives you—in study after study provides the greatest return over time. However if you are not tough enough to stay the course or if you get scared and bail when the storms are raging, you are going to drown. But that’s a psychological failure, not a downside of this asset class. As

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: For the wealth accumulation stage an allocation of 100% stocks using VTSAX is the soul of simplicity. But as we’ve seen, some studies suggest that adding a small percentage of bonds—say 10-25%—actually outperforms 100% stocks.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: be careful not to buy more VTSAX in your IRA, or any other of your investment accounts, within 30 days of selling. If you do, the IRS will consider this a “wash sale” and your tax loss would be negated.)

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: Note the expense ratio is just .05%, the same as that of the Admiral Shares. For this reason some people prefer to buy the ETF rather than the Investor Shares fund. Makes sense, but be careful. When buying or selling ETFs, just like a stock, commissions and/or spreads are frequently involved. These added costs can offset the savings in the expense ratio unless you have access to free trading.

Title: The Simple Path to Wealth: Your road map to financial independence and a rich, free life
Author: JL Collins and Mr. Money Mustache
Highlight Text: The great irony of successful investing is that simple is cheaper and more profitable. Complicated investments only benefit the people and companies that sell them.

But the evidence on the screen strongly suggests that these were people trying to make something fun for others to enjoy, something largely innocent, not trying to open up any windows on the abyss.

Title: Wolf in White Van: A Novel
Author: John Darnielle
Highlight Text: Stores where I live are as big as college campuses. But sometimes I’ll get stir-crazy, and I’ll start to resent that I can’t put my life through the same paces everybody else takes for granted. So I’ll go out in the morning, out the door by nine o’clock at the latest, and I’ll substitute the liquor store for the supermarket, since early-riser liquor store shoppers are people who wouldn’t raise their eyes to you if you had a gun pointed at them. Besides which, I have a special place in my heart for the Pomona liquor stores that face the empty boulevards. I grew up in them, kind of: they used to have comic racks.

Title: Wolf in White Van: A Novel
Author: John Darnielle
Highlight Text: When you shoot yourself in the face with a Marlin 39A, one thing you don’t think about is what your father will tell his mother when it becomes necessary to tell her something’s happened.

Title: Wolf in White Van: A Novel
Author: John Darnielle
Highlight Text: I have a theory that the less you say when someone dies, the better. Leave everything as open as you can.

Title: Wolf in White Van: A Novel
Author: John Darnielle
Highlight Text: This I do by pretending everything is normal; the secret is to believe it in your heart, which comes more naturally than you’d think.

Title: Wolf in White Van: A Novel
Author: John Darnielle
Highlight Text: the group leader talked everybody through inner journeys to weird places, like a lake in the forest, and you were supposed to go there in your mind and feel at peace. It worked, in a way, though I always saw other things in the forest, which I kept to myself.

Title: Wolf in White Van: A Novel
Author: John Darnielle
Highlight Text: I never look up when people honk at me because I don’t want any trouble. People gave me trouble back then because of the way I dressed and because they didn’t like my friends. Inside I hated anybody who honked at me and wished I could cause their car to crash using only the powers of my mind.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: When you make a business, you get to make a little universe where you control all the laws. This is your utopia. When you make it a dream come true for yourself, it’ll be a dream come true for someone else, too.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: Don’t waste years fighting uphill battles against locked doors. Improve or invent until you get that huge response.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: Starting small puts 100 percent of your energy into actually solving real problems for real people. It gives you a stronger foundation to grow from.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: To me, ideas are worth nothing unless they are executed. They are just a multiplier. Execution is worth millions.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: When someone’s doing something for love, being generous instead of stingy, trusting instead of fearful, it triggers this law: We want to give to those who give.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: Life is good. You can’t prevent bad things from happening. Learn to shrug. Resist the urge to punish everyone for one person’s mistake.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: When we yell at our car or our coffee machine, it’s fine because they’re just mechanical appliances. So when we yell at a website or a company, using our computer or our phone, we forget that it’s not an appliance but a person that’s affected. It’s dehumanizing to have thousands of people passing through our computer screens, so we do things we’d never do if those people were sitting next to us.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: When you’re thinking of how to make your business bigger, it’s tempting to try to think all the big thoughts and come up with world-changing massive-action plans. But please know that it’s often the tiny details that really thrill people enough to make them tell all their friends about you.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: There’s a benefit to being naive about the norms of the world—deciding from scratch what seems like the right thing to do, instead of just doing what others do.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: To be a true business owner, make it so that you could leave for a year, and when you came back, your business would be doing better than when you left.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: Never forget that you can make your role anything you want it to be. Anything you hate to do, someone else loves. So find that person and let her do it.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: Happiness is the real reason you’re doing anything, right? Even if you say it’s for the money, the money is just a means to happiness, isn’t it? But what if it’s proven that after a certain point, money doesn’t create any happiness at all, but only headaches? You may be much happier as a $1 million business than a $1 billion business.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: I learned a hard lesson in hindsight: Trust, but verify. Remember it when delegating. You have to do both.

Title: Anything You Want: 40 Lessons for a New Kind of Entrepreneur
Author: Derek Sivers
Highlight Text: I learned an important word: abdicate. To abdicate means to surrender or relinquish power or responsibility; this word is usually used when a king abdicates the throne or crown. Lesson learned too late: Delegate, but don’t abdicate.

If a thing existed up here, it was because it belonged here. And if it didn’t belong, the people who lived here made damn sure it didn’t stay.

Title: Bull Mountain

Highlight Text: Silo 1’s Security chief now counted down shifts much as he had once counted down years to retirement. Let them be uneventful, was his mantra. The blandness was good. Vanilla was the taste of passing time. Such was his thought as he stood before an open cryopod splattered with dried blood, a foul taste very un-vanilla-like in his mouth.

Title: Dust (Silo series Book 3)

Highlight Text: They ought to have been left on their own, both people and the planet. Mankind had the right to go extinct. That’s what life did: it went extinct. It made room for the next in line.

Author: Hugh Howey
Highlight Text: Their days were counted. The idea of saving anything was folly, a life especially. No life had ever been truly saved, not in the history of mankind. They were merely prolonged. Everything comes to an end.

Author: Hugh Howey
Highlight Text: Him not taking her in felt like a bad thing, like he was operating outside the rules. She had seen men in Iraq operate outside the rules. It was never to do anything good.

Title: Dust (Silo series Book 3)

Highlight Text: The trip up the stairwell was heavier with that blessing. Or maybe it was the weight of the explosives on her back, which Juliette knew would’ve been useful for the tunneling below.

Highlight Text: People can find patterns in all kinds of random events. It’s called apophenia. It’s the tendency we humans have to find meaning in disconnected information. For example, some people believe in what’s called the ‘twenty-three enigma.’ That everything is related to the number twenty-three. It’s a surprisingly involved belief.”

Author: Dan Chaon
Highlight Text: This little island that I’d built for myself, this family that had seemed so safe and stable, was dissipating beneath my feet.

When the therapist begins to confess secrets to the patient. When, somehow, you have bonded with them, they have almost become your therapist.

Title: Ill Will: A Novel
Author: Dan Chaon
Highlight Text: “We live in capitalism,” she said. “For better and worse. Disproportionate numbers of bad things happen to people who are economically disadvantaged.”

Author: Dan Chaon
Highlight Text: It was not an impressive river, in my opinion. About as wide as a suburban street, and the same dirty gray shade as the sky. Not water you would drink from. Eigengrau.

Author: Dan Chaon
Highlight Text: We look at them in one dimension, and it seems that they are all connected. We think that there’s some image we can make out if we connect the dots. But more than likely the dots are not connected.  They’re on separate geometric planes, light-years apart.

Title: Ill Will: A Novel
Author: Dan Chaon
Highlight Text: Unfortunately there can be no doubt that man is, on the whole, less good than he imagines himself or wants to be. Everyone carries a shadow, and the less it is embodied in the individual’s conscious life, the blacker and denser it is.

Title: Ill Will: A Novel
Author: Dan Chaon
Highlight Text: When you’re high, driving feels so good. You have your hands on the steering wheel and the world outside looks like a video game that you are controlling, and your eyes are sharp and focused but your mind is sifting out behind you like sand blowing off a dune; you feel it rolling away from you even as you move forward steadily.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: “Well, Danny?” she asked. “No one will ever replace Ellen, but it’s better than nothing,” he said. “Life’s a balance. Nature treated you harshly today. This restores the balance. You can take her,” Ma said.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: Your body is a longbow carved from hickory, her father said. Your body is a blade sharpened by tears, her mother said.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: “I am Trouble with a capital T. I’m Death with a capital D. If you give me any problems at all, I won’t hesitate to kill you. Do you understand?”

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: She knew if he pulled the trigger, she wouldn’t feel a thing. She wouldn’t hear anything. Her life would instantly cut to black. The blackness would last until the end of the universe, when everything would be black.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: There were no monsters on Dutch Island, but the beast was man, had always been man.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: A black iron nothingness. An ellipsis of time. Perhaps a minute; perhaps ten thousand million years. A nimbus of yellow goblin light.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: It was night, and the barbarians were coming. The only question was whether the barbarians were them or her.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: She squeezed the trigger, and the rifle thumped comfortingly into her right shoulder. The explosive in the cartridge threw out a lead ogive that the barrel spiraled into the air with the faintest rush of smoke and the sweet smell of gunpowder. The bullet had been on a collision course with its target since it was manufactured in North London in 1941.

Title: The Island
Author: Adrian McKinty
Highlight Text: You know what she is, Matthew? She’s the monster. The bunyip. She’ll destroy us unless we destroy her. We got to get her.”

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: I made a decision that while cancer may define how I die, it would not define how I live.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: The journey of The Last Arrow begins when you raise the bar. We need to raise the bar of our standards of our faith, of our sacrifice, of our expectations of ourselves, of our belief of the goodness and generosity of God.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: I wonder how many times in my own life I thought I failed but actually the only thing that happened was that I quit.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Wouldn’t it be better for all of us if we were incapable of knowing that there’s more? How often is our greatest torment, that haunting thought, that the lives we long to live are not the lives we were created to live?

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Maybe those of us most aware of our imperfections and flaws are best suited for this journey. After all, what do we have to lose? We were never supposed to amount to anything. If failure is our inevitable future, then let’s fail boldly and fail forward.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: But the moments that will actually define us, the moments that will carry the greatest weight in our lives, the moments that will create for us the future we’ve always longed for, are not those moments that easily integrate into our past, but instead they are the disruptive moments, the moments when we must choose between extending our past and creating our future.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: If slavery remains an option, we will find ourselves abdicating our freedom. We just don’t usually call it slavery. We call it safety. We call it comfort. We call it security. We call it responsibility.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: It’s not that those who settle for less don’t want more for their lives; it’s that they want the “more” where they are and are not willing to go where the “more” is waiting for them. Yet over and over again, we find that God presses against us and forces us to choose.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: We are afraid that if we leave something behind in our past, there is not something better waiting for us in the future.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Sometimes, though, it’s not the people who keep us in the past; it’s our own sense of identity.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: There is a subtle difference between your identity being rooted in your essence and your identity being rooted in your success. What you do comes out of who you are, but who you are must exist apart from what you do.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Success is a tyrant that will enslave you just as quickly as failure. If you let success own you, you will find yourself trapped by your success and terrified by the possibility of failure.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: If those trophies are the highlights of our lives, then our lives were not worth living, going forward. Those trophies were the past, and it would be a waste of our time and effort to try to reclaim the past. It would be much better for us to focus on creating the future.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Setting your past on fire is not about self-destructive behavior. In fact, it is quite the opposite. It is about making the hard decisions to leave behind that which would steal from you the future God intends for you.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: It’s more important to get where you are going than to take what you brought with you.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Refuse to stay behind. Never ever opt out of the opportunities that move you in the direction of your dreams, your purpose, your passions.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: People who are constantly praying about everything may be doing too much talking and not enough listening. The point of prayer is response. And once God has spoken, you don’t need to pray about that anymore—unless, of course, you are trying to change his mind.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Life is cruel in this: if you are willing to be left behind, the future will leave you in the past and opportunity will depart.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: When God tells you to strike an arrow, you just keep striking and striking and striking and you do not stop until you hear heaven shout, “It is finished.”

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Don’t wait to be asked—volunteer. Volunteer to go forward. Volunteer to go further. Volunteer to go harder. You cannot pioneer out of obligation. It is not an adventure if it is not your choice. You have to want it. You have to want more. If you are going to be greedy, this is the right place to be greedy. Want everything God has for you. Want more than others think you can obtain. Why settle for a single portion if a double portion can be yours for the asking?

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: cannot ensure how long I live, but I can determine that I will live fully while I’m alive.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Too many of us act as if we’re going to live forever or that life can wait until we’re ready to live it. But when it comes to life, we get no trial runs. We get no practice games. And when it comes to life, you need to act as though your life depends on it.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: For Shammah, there is no point in running for your life if once you get there you have no reason to live.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: All of us, whether consciously or unconsciously, find a piece of ground where we choose to take our stand. Yet the reality is that for far too many of us, the place where we set our feet is rarely the result of a decisive decision to stop running and start fighting.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: How strange that there are people in this world who have taken more care to decide where they will die than how they will live.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: We think that life is either a sprint or a marathon but that in either case we are the only runner who matters. If life is a race, it is far more like a relay in which we do not win if we do not have a team that will help us get across the finish line.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: we are more powerful when we walk together, and we are more vulnerable when we walk alone.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: How you end is profoundly affected by how you begin. You never begin the journey of creating the life you want until you know what you want. It’s only when you know what you want that you can say no to everything that wants you.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: If you don’t know what you want, then God’s trying to give you what he wants for you is a wasted effort. You have to want what God wants in order to receive what he wants to give you.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: If we choose to live a small life, we do not make enough room for a big God.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: If you don’t know what you want, you will get what you do not want. If you don’t know who you want to become, you will become someone you never wanted to be. If you don’t know what life you want to live, you’re going to live the life someone else wants you to live. If you don’t know what you want God to do in your life, you will wonder why he gave you so little, while the whole time he was waiting for you to see how much he wanted to entrust with you.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Be faithful in the small things that do not matter to you as much and treat them with the same level of respect and importance as the big things connected to your hopes and dreams.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: it is the person who is faithful in the small things who will be entrusted with bigger things.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: “When the body touched Elisha’s bones,” we’re told, “the man came to life and stood up on his feet.”3 I think this is a not-so-subtle reminder that if you truly live before you die, your life will have a power that not even death can conquer.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Though it was a tragic death, there’s something strangely beautiful about that moment: being able to whisper with your last breath one word that lets the world know you did exactly what you were born to do. In that moment, death has no power, death has no victory. There is no regret—only a deep sense of fulfillment.

Title: The Last Arrow: Save Nothing for the Next Life
Author: Erwin Raphael McManus
Highlight Text: Ralph Waldo Emerson said, “The way to write is to throw your body at the mark when your arrows are spent.”6 I agree wholeheartedly, except I would add one particular nuance: that the way to live is to throw your body at the mark when your arrows are spent.

Title: The Inner Game of Tennis: The Classic Guide to the Mental Side of Peak Performance

Highlight Text: Do we really think the value of a human being is measurable? It doesn’t really make sense to measure ourselves in comparison with other immeasurable beings. In fact, we are what we are; we are not how well we happen to perform at a given moment. The grade on a report card may measure an ability in arithmetic, but it doesn’t measure the person’s value. Similarly, the score of a tennis match may be an indication of how well I performed or how hard I tried, but it does not define me, nor give me cause to consider myself as something more or less than I was before the match.

Title: The Inner Game of Tennis: The Classic Guide to the Mental Side of Peak Performance
Author: W. Timothy Gallwey, Pete Carroll, Bill Gates, and Zach Kleiman
Highlight Text: The surfer waits for the big wave because he values the challenge it presents. He values the obstacles the wave puts between him and his goal of riding the wave to the beach. Why? Because it is those very obstacles, the size and churning power of the wave, which draw from the surfer his greatest effort. It is only against the big waves that he is required to use all his skill, all his courage and concentration to overcome; only then can he realize the true limits of his capacities.

Title: The Inner Game of Tennis: The Classic Guide to the Mental Side of Peak Performance

Highlight Text: Each player tries his hardest to defeat the other, but in this use of competition it isn’t the other person we are defeating; it is simply a matter of overcoming the obstacles he presents. In true competition no person is defeated. Both players benefit by their efforts to overcome the obstacles presented by the other.

Title: The Inner Game of Tennis: The Classic Guide to the Mental Side of Peak Performance

Title: The Inner Game of Tennis: The Classic Guide to the Mental Side of Peak Performance

Highlight Text: “When it comes to overcoming obstacles, there are three kinds of people. The first kind sees most obstacles as insurmountable and walks away. The second kind sees an obstacle and says, I can overcome it, and starts to dig under, climb over, or blast through it. The third type of person, before deciding to overcome the obstacle, tries to find a viewpoint where what is on the other side of the obstacle can be seen. Then, only if the reward is worth the effort, does he attempt to overcome the obstacle.”

Title: SEO 2025: Learn search engine optimization with smart internet marketing strategies
Author: Adam Clarke
Highlight Text: Along came a new Google update in 2012, this time called Penguin. Google's Penguin update punished sites with suspicious amounts of links with the same anchor text pointing to a page, by completely delisting sites from the search results. Many businesses that relied on search engine traffic lost all of their sales literally overnight, just because Google believed sites with hundreds of links containing just one phrase didn't acquire those links naturally. Google believed this was a solid indicator the site owner could be gaming the system.

Title: SEO 2025: Learn search engine optimization with smart internet marketing strategies
Author: Adam Clarke
Highlight Text: Here’s a short list of the strongest factors in the top 10 search results, according to recent industry studies: - Direct website visits. - Click-through-rate. - Time-on-site. - Bounce rate (low bounce rates are better). - Number and quality of backlinks. - HTTPS—security certificate installed on site. - Overall content relevance and keyword usage. - Font size in main content area (presumably people find larger fonts more readable and leads to higher engagement). - Number of images. - Total social media activity.

Title: SEO 2025: Learn search engine optimization with smart internet marketing strategies
Author: Adam Clarke
Highlight Text: long-tail, informational and transactional keywords are good keywords for most SEO projects. They will lead to more customers.

Title: SEO 2025: Learn search engine optimization with smart internet marketing strategies
Author: Adam Clarke
Highlight Text: Keep a close eye on popular and trending topics, and questions with a tendency to resurface. You'll find burning questions needing to be answered, generating the best kind of keyword ideas—keywords directly from customer’s keyboards.

Title: SEO 2025: Learn search engine optimization with smart internet marketing strategies
Author: Adam Clarke
Highlight Text: Find two or three related keywords to your main keyword and repeat these in the page once or two times each. LSIGraph is a great tool for finding keywords

Title: SEO 2025: Learn search engine optimization with smart internet marketing strategies
Author: Adam Clarke
Highlight Text: But just to be safe, your directory links should not make up much more than 10-20% of your total links.
