Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: IN THE morning when thou risest unwillingly, let this thought be present- I am rising to the work of a human being.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: And art thou unwilling to do the work of a human being, and dost thou not make haste to do that which is according to thy nature?- But it is necessary to take rest also.- It is necessary: however nature has fixed bounds to this too: she has fixed bounds both to eating and drinking, and yet thou goest beyond these bounds, beyond what is sufficient;

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: As a horse when he has run, a dog when he has tracked the game, a bee when it has made the honey, so a man when he has done a good act, does not call out for others to come and see, but he goes on to another act, as a vine goes on to produce again the grapes in season.- Must a man then be one of these, who in a manner act thus without observing it?- Yes.-

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Be not disgusted, nor discouraged, nor dissatisfied, if thou dost not succeed in doing everything according to right principles; but when thou bast failed, return back again, and be content if the greater part of what thou doest is consistent with man's nature, and love this to which thou returnest; and do not return to philosophy as if she were a master, but act like those who have sore eyes and apply a bit of sponge and egg, or as another applies a plaster, or drenching with water.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: certain moments are torn from us, that some are gently removed, and that others glide beyond our reach. The most disgraceful kind of loss, however, is that due to carelessness. Furthermore, if you will pay close heed to the problem, you will find that the largest portion of our life passes while we are doing ill, a goodly share while we are doing nothing, and the whole while we are doing that which is not to the purpose. What man can you show me who places any value on his time, who reckons the worth of each day, who understands that he is dying daily?

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: You do not run hither and thither and distract yourself by changing your abode; for such restlessness is the sign of a disordered spirit. The primary indication, to my thinking, of a well-ordered mind is a man's ability to remain in one place and linger in his own company.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Each day acquire something that will fortify you against poverty, against death, indeed against other misfortunes as well; and after you have run over many thoughts, select one to be thoroughly digested that day.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "Contented poverty is an honourable estate." Indeed, if it be contented, it is not poverty at all. It is not the man who has too little, but the man who craves more, that is poor.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Do you ask what is the proper limit to wealth? It is, first, to have what is necessary, and, second, to have what is enough. Farewell.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Boys fear trifles, children fear shadows, we fear both.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Death arrives; it would be a thing to dread, if it could remain with you. But death must either not come at all, or else must come and pass away.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "What progress, you ask, have I made? I have begun to be a friend to myself." That was indeed a great benefit; such a person can never be alone. You may be sure that such a man is a friend to all mankind. Farewell.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Do you ask me what you should regard as especially to be avoided? I say, crowds; for as yet you cannot trust yourself to them with safety. I shall admit my own weakness, at any rate; for I never bring back home the same character that I took abroad with me. Something of that which I have forced to be calm within me is disturbed; some of the foes that I have routed return again.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: To consort with the crowd is harmful; there is no person who does not make some vice attractive to us, or stamp it upon us, or taint us unconsciously therewith. Certainly, the greater the mob with which we mingle, the greater the danger.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "Avoid whatever pleases the throng: avoid the gifts of Chance! Halt before every good which Chance brings to you, in a spirit of doubt and fear; for it is the dumb animals and fish that are deceived by tempting hopes. Do you call these things the 'gifts' of Fortune? They are snares. And any man among you who wishes to live a life of safety will avoid, to the utmost of his power, these limed twigs of her favour, by which we mortals, most wretched in this respect also, are deceived; for we think that we hold them in our grasp, but they hold us in theirs. Such a career leads us into precipitous ways, and life on such heights ends in a fall. Moreover, we cannot even stand up against prosperity when she begins to drive us to leeward; nor can we go down, either, 'with the ship at least on her course,' or once for all; Fortune does not capsize us, – she plunges our bows under and dashes us on the rocks.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: But we and they alike hold this idea, – that the wise man is self-sufficient. Nevertheless, he desires friends, neighbours, and associates, no matter how much he is sufficient unto himself. And mark how self-sufficient he is; for on occasion he can be content with a part of himself. If he lose a hand through disease or war, or if some accident puts out one or both of his eyes, he will be satisfied with what is left, taking as much pleasure in his impaired and maimed body as he took when it was sound. But while he does not pine for these parts if they are missing, he prefers not to lose them. In this sense the wise man is self-sufficient, that he can do without friends, not that he desires to do without them. When I say "can," I mean this: he endures the loss of a friend with equanimity.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: The philosopher Attalus used to say: "It is more pleasant to make than to keep a friend, as it is more pleasant to the artist to paint than to have finished painting." When one is busy and absorbed in one's work, the very absorption affords great delight; but when one has withdrawn one's hand from the completed masterpiece, the pleasure is not so keen. Henceforth it is the fruits of his art that he enjoys; it was the art itself that he enjoyed while he was painting.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: These are the so-called "fair-weather" friendships; one who is chosen for the sake of utility will be satisfactory only so long as he is useful. Hence prosperous men are blockaded by troops of friends; but those who have failed stand amid vast loneliness their friends fleeing from the very crisis which is to test their worth.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: He who begins to be your friend because it pays will also cease because it pays. A man will be attracted by some reward offered in exchange for his friendship, if he be attracted by aught in friendship other than friendship itself.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: The Supreme Good calls for no practical aids from outside; it is developed at home, and arises entirely within itself. If the good seeks any portion of itself from without, it begins to be subject to the play of Fortune.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Crates, they say, the disciple of the very Stilbo whom I mentioned in a former letter, noticed a young man walking by himself, and asked him what he was doing all alone. "I am communing with myself," replied the youth. "Pray be careful, then," said Crates, "and take good heed; you are communing with a bad man!"

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: For our powers can never inspire in us implicit faith in ourselves except when many difficulties have confronted us on this side and on that, and have occasionally even come to close quarters with us. It is only in this way that the true spirit can be tested, – the spirit that will never consent to come under the jurisdiction of things external to ourselves. This is the touchstone of such a spirit; no prizefighter can go with high spirits into the strife if he has never been beaten black and blue; the only contestant who can confidently enter the lists is the man who has seen his own blood, who has felt his teeth rattle beneath his opponent's fist, who has been tripped and felt the full force of his adversary's charge, who has been downed in body but not in spirit, one who, as often as he falls, rises again with greater defiance than ever.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Do me the favour, when men surround you and try to talk you into believing that you are unhappy, to consider not what you hear but what you yourself feel, and to take counsel with your feelings and question yourself independently, because you know your own affairs better than anyone else does.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Let us, then, look carefully into the matter. It is likely that some troubles will befall us; but it is not a present fact. How often has the unexpected happened! How often has the expected never come to pass! And even though it is ordained to be, what does it avail to run out to meet your suffering? You will suffer soon enough, when it arrives; so look forward meanwhile to better things. What shall you gain by doing this? Time. There will be many happenings meanwhile which will serve to postpone, or end, or pass on to another person, the trials which are near or even in your very presence.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Even bad fortune is fickle. Perhaps it will come, perhaps not; in the meantime it is not. So look forward to better things.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "The fool, with all his other faults, has this also, he is always getting ready to live."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: We should conduct ourselves not as if we ought to live for the body, but as if we could not live without it.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: We should cherish the body with the greatest care; but we should also be prepared, when reason, self-respect, and duty demand the sacrifice, to deliver it even to the flames.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "He who needs riches least, enjoys riches most."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: It is clear to you, I am sure, Lucilius, that no man can live a happy life, or even a supportable life, without the study of wisdom; you know also that a happy life is reached when our wisdom is brought to completion, but that life is at least endurable even when our wisdom is only begun.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: This also is a saying of Epicurus: "If you live according to nature, you will never be poor; if you live according to opinion, you will never be rich."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Natural desires are limited; but those which spring from false opinion can have no stopping-point. The false has no limits. When you are travelling on a road, there must be an end; but when astray, your wanderings are limitless.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: If you find, after having travelled far, that there is a more distant goal always in view, you may be sure that this condition is contrary to nature.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: If you wish to have leisure for your mind, either be a poor man, or resemble a poor man. Study cannot be helpful unless you take pains to live simply; and living simply is voluntary poverty.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "I wish to acquire something to live on." Yes, but learn while you are acquiring it; for if anything forbids you to live nobly, nothing forbids you to die nobly.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Wisdom offers wealth in ready money, and pays it over to those in whose eyes she has made wealth superfluous." These remarks refer to other men; you are nearer the rich class. Change the age in which you live, and you have too much. But in every age, what is enough remains the same.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Just as it matters little whether you lay a sick man on a wooden or on a golden bed, for whithersoever he be moved he will carry his malady with him; so one need not care whether the diseased mind is bestowed upon riches or upon poverty. His malady goes with the man.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: It is the month of December, and yet the city is at this very moment in a sweat. License is given to the general merrymaking. Everything resounds with mighty preparations, – as if the Saturnalia differed at all from the usual business day! So true it is that the difference is nil, that I regard as correct the remark of the man who said: "Once December was a month; now it is a year."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: It shows much more courage to remain dry and sober when the mob is drunk and vomiting; but it shows greater self-control to refuse to withdraw oneself and to do what the crowd does, but in a different way, – thus neither making oneself conspicuous nor becoming one of the crowd. For one may keep holiday without extravagance.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Let us practise our strokes on the "dummy"; let us become intimate with poverty, so that Fortune may not catch us off our guard. We shall be rich with all the more comfort, if we once learn how far poverty is from being a burden.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: So begin, my dear Lucilius, to follow the custom of these men, and set apart certain days on which you shall withdraw from your business and make yourself at home with the scantiest fare. Establish business relations with poverty.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: A trifling debt makes a man your debtor; a large one makes him an enemy.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Observe yourself, then, and see whether your dress and your house are inconsistent, whether you treat yourself lavishly and your family meanly, whether you eat frugal dinners and yet build luxurious houses.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: No man is born rich. Every man, when he first sees light, is commanded to be content with milk and rags. Such is our beginning, and yet kingdoms are all too small for us!

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: The deep flood of time will roll over us; some few great men will raise their heads above it, and, though destined at the last to depart into the same realms of silence, will battle against oblivion and maintain their ground for long.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "Everyone goes out of life just as if he had but lately entered it." Take anyone off his guard, young, old, or middle-aged; you will find that all are equally afraid of death, and equally ignorant of life. No one has anything finished, because we have kept putting off into the future all our undertakings. No thought in the quotation given above pleases me more than that it taunts old men with being infants. "No one," he says, "leaves this world in a different manner from one who has just been born."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Nature should scold us, saying: "What does this mean? I brought you into the world without desires or fears, free from superstition, treachery and the other curses. Go forth as you were when you entered!"

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Men do not care how nobly they live, but only how long, although it is within the reach of every man to live nobly, but within no man's power to live long. Farewell.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: That you see happening to boys happens also to ourselves, who are only slightly bigger boys: when those whom they love, with whom they daily associate, with whom they play, appear with masks on, the boys are frightened out of their wits.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Say to yourself that our petty bodies are mortal and frail; pain can reach them from other sources than from wrong or the might of the stronger.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "I shall die," you say; you mean to say "I shall cease to run the risk of sickness; I shall cease to run the risk of imprisonment; I shall cease to run the risk of death."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: we do not suddenly fall on death, but advance towards it by slight degrees; we die every day. For every day a little of our life is taken from us; even when we are growing, our life is on the wane. We lose our childhood, then our boyhood, and then our youth. Counting even yesterday, all past time is lost time; the very day which we are now spending is shared between ourselves and death.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Not single is the death which comes; the death Which takes us off is but the last of all.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Night is close at the heels of day, day at the heels of night; summer ends in autumn, winter rushes after autumn, and winter softens into spring; all nature in this way passes, only to return. I do nothing new; I see nothing new; sooner or later one sickens of this, also." There are many who think that living is not painful, but superfluous.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: There is no fixed count of our years. You do not know where death awaits you; so be ready for it everywhere.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Indeed, have you already advised yourself, already corrected your own faults? Is this the reason why you have leisure to reform other men?" No, I am not so shameless as to undertake to cure my fellow-men when I am ill myself.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Just as crimes, even if they have not been detected when they were committed, do not allow anxiety to end with them; so with guilty pleasures, regret remains even after the pleasures are over.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: No man is able to borrow or buy a sound mind; in fact, as it seems to me, even though sound minds were for sale, they would not find buyers. Depraved minds, however, are bought and sold every day.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Lands and cities are left astern   your faults will follow you whithersoever you travel.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: What pleasure is there in seeing new lands? Or in surveying cities and spots of interest? All your bustle is useless. Do you ask why such flight does not help you? It is because you flee along with yourself. You must lay aside the burdens of the mind; until you do this, no place will satisfy you.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: The person you are matters more than the place to which you go; for that reason we should not make the mind a bondsman to any one place. Live in this belief: "I am not born for any one corner of the universe; this whole world is my country."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: "There were thirty tyrants surrounding Socrates, and yet they could not break his spirit"; but what does it matter how many masters a man has? "Slavery" has no plural; and he who has scorned it is free, – no matter amid how large a mob of over-lords he stands.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Just so, there are not many who have access to you to slay you, though there are many who threaten you with death. Nature has so ordered it that, as only one has given you life, so only one will take it away.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: I hold that one is braver at the very moment of death than when one is approaching death. For death, when it stands near us, gives even to inexperienced men the courage not to seek to avoid the inevitable. So the gladiator, who throughout the fight has been no matter how faint-hearted, offers his throat to his opponent and directs the wavering blade to the vital spot.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: it is as foolish to fear death as to fear old age; for death follows old age precisely as old age follows youth. He who does not wish to die cannot have wished to live. For life is granted to us with the reservation that we shall die; to this end our path leads. Therefore, how foolish it is to fear it, since men simply await that which is sure, but fear only that which is uncertain!

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: But who is not near death? It is ready for us in all places and at all times. "Let us consider," he went on to say, "when some agency of death seems imminent, how much nearer are other varieties of dying which are not feared by us."

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: We do not fear death; we fear the thought of death. For death itself is always the same distance from us; wherefore, if it is to be feared at all, it is to be feared always. For what season of our life is exempt from death?

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Just as nothing gleams if it has no light blended with it, and nothing is black unless it contains darkness or draws to itself something of dimness, and as nothing is hot without the aid of fire, and nothing cold without air; so it is the association of virtue and vice that makes things honourable or base.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Those who have never attained their mental independence begin, in the first place, by following the leader in cases where everyone has deserted the leader; then, in the second place, they follow him in matters where the truth is still being investigated. However, the truth will never be discovered if we rest contented with discoveries already made.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: A shifting of the will indicates that the mind is at sea, heading in various directions, according to the course of the wind. But that which is settled and solid does not wander from its place.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: just as it is creditable for every age to study, so it is not creditable for every age to be instructed. An old man learning his A B C is a disgraceful and absurd object; the young man must store up, the old man must use.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: you later, with more care, that everything which seems to perish merely changes. Since you are destined to return, you ought to depart with a tranquil mind.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Then it is that the height of unhappiness is reached, when men are not only attracted, but even pleased, by shameful things, and when there is no longer any room for a cure, now that those things which once were vices have become habits.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: Therefore, mark my words; that forceful manner of speech, rapid and copious, is more suited to a mountebank than to a man who is discussing and teaching an important and serious subject. But I object just as strongly that he should drip out his words as that he should go at top speed; he should neither keep the ear on the stretch, nor deafen it.

Title: Stoic Six Pack (Illustrated): Meditations of Marcus Aurelius, Golden Sayings, Fragments and Discourses of Epictetus, Letters from a Stoic and The Enchiridion
Author: Various Artists
Highlight Text: And yet that were the better choice, for the rapidity of Quintus Haterius, the most famous orator of his age, is, in my opinion, to be avoided by a man of sense. Haterius never hesitated, never paused; he made only one start, and only one stop.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Here’s the breaking news: your self-talk is fucking you over and in ways you can’t even begin to imagine.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: the person who views success as if it were just around the corner will not only work his butt off to achieve it but be energized and alive to it and all the while acting on that fundamental view of success.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: people spend their lives waiting for the cavalry, all the while never realizing they are the cavalry. Your life is waiting on you to finally show up.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Assertive self-talk is when you stake a claim for this moment of time, right here and now. When you start to talk in terms of “I am . . .” or “I embrace . . .” or “I accept . . .” or “I assert . . . ,” all of which are powerful and commanding uses of language rather than the narrative of “I will . . .” or “I’m going to .

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Getting straight with yourself about having made the decision to stay where you are can be just as powerful as the decision to move.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Making sure we’re striving for what we really want requires a constant check-in with ourselves. It’s not a one-and-done deal.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Instead of wasting time worrying about the things other people have, you’ll start focusing on what’s really important to you and your life. You’ll realize that once you replace envy, lust, and desire with a willingness to change your life for the better, things really start to take shape.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: What if I don’t want this life? Fine; but this is the one you’re currently winning at.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: You’re always winning because your brain is wired to. The trouble comes when what you really want—on a subconscious level—and what you say you want are different, sometimes radically so.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: In his research, Dr. Bruce Lipton, the famous stem cell and DNA scientist, found that 95 percent of what we do in our day-to-day life is controlled by our subconscious.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Many of my clients, I have found, have one particular thing in common: the subconscious desire to prove that their parents did a bad job raising them.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: you’re struggling to get work done, perhaps you believe that you’re incapable or lazy. You prove that idea every single time you pause or procrastinate. You’re proving to yourself and others that you really are that person.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: “The happiness of your life depends upon the quality of your thoughts. Therefore, guard accordingly, and take that you entertain no notions unsuitable to virtue and reasonable nature.” - Marcus Aurelius

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: The thing is, the negative experiences we have rarely stay contained to that one issue. They spread. Like a toxic chemical, they seep into all aspects of our lives.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: As you examine all the things you’ve experienced and all the things you’ve yet to experience, take a moment to examine what you are currently dealing with today. Everything on your plate at this point in time is just another something in a sea of somethings.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Face your problems as they come, one by one; give them the attention they need and move on.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: “I got this” doesn’t mean you have the perfect solution. It just means you have your hands on the wheel, you have a say in this just like you’ve had a say all along. I mean come on, you live for this shit!

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: You’re out of control and so dependent on your drug of choice, you don’t even realize how it’s affecting your life. You have a gnawing craving and that craving is for prediction.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Uncertainty is your personal pathway to opportunity. It’s the environment in which you grow, experience new things, and produce new, unprecedented results. Uncertainty is where new happens.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: “In any moment of decision, the best thing you can do is the right thing, the next best thing is the wrong thing, and the worst thing you can do is nothing.” - Theodore Roosevelt

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: By running from uncertainty in search of certainty, we’re actually rejecting the one thing in life that is guaranteed in favor of something that’s nothing more than a fantasy.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: The more we try to stay comfortable today, the more uncomfortable we’ll be tomorrow. There really is no destination, there is only exploring, exploring, and exploring.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Remember, all of the successes, all of the experiences, all of the things you’ve always dreamed of are waiting for you in uncertainty.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Focus on the things you can control and release yourself from worrying about what you can’t, like the weather, the Dow Jones, or what your neighbor thinks about your haircut.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: YOU ARE NOT YOUR THOUGHTS You are not your thoughts. You are not defined by what’s inside your head. You are what you do. Your actions.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: It’s all about action. Going out there, doing it, and taking all your negative bullshit along for the ride. It’s never going to get any better, any easier, or any more understandable. This is it, life is now and you’re never going to have a better moment than this.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: We often expect other people to treat us exactly as we treat them. If we do them a favor, we expect to get the same favor back in return. It becomes an unspoken “debt” of sorts. When we give our partner a foot massage, we expect them to reciprocate either directly or indirectly. Those expectations grow in both weight and complexity in an intimate or romantic relationship.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: The desire to work on our “procrastination” just leaves us stuck in the cycle of procrastination and not-procrastination and keeps us even further from forwarding our actual lives.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: When we feel “off,” we put our lives off. That’s right, you’re waiting on a feeling.

Title: Unfu*k Yourself: Get Out of Your Head and into Your Life (Unfu*k Yourself series)
Author: Gary John Bishop
Highlight Text: Just like how we improve our internal by moving to the external, we can forget our past by creating a future. Build something big, something

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: He was looking anxious and worried, like a man who has done the murder all right but can't think what the deuce to do with the body.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: Muriel Singer was one of those very quiet, appealing girls who have a way of looking at you with their big eyes as if they thought you were the greatest thing on earth and wondered that you hadn't got on to it yet yourself. She sat there in a sort of shrinking way, looking at me as if she were saying to herself, "Oh, I do hope this great strong man isn't going to hurt me."

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: She was rather like one of those innocent-tasting American drinks which creep imperceptibly into your system so that, before you know what you're doing, you're starting out to reform the world by force if necessary and pausing on your way to tell the large man in the corner that, if he looks at you like that, you will knock his head off.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: I always used to think that publishers had to be devilish intelligent fellows, loaded down with the grey matter; but I've got their number now. All a publisher has to do is to write cheques at intervals, while a lot of deserving and industrious chappies rally round and do the real work. I know, because I've been one myself. I simply sat tight in the old apartment with a fountain-pen, and in due season a topping, shiny book came along.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: She fitted into my biggest arm-chair as if it had been built round her by someone who knew they were wearing arm-chairs tight about the hips that season.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: If ever you see me sober, old top," he said, with a kind of holy exaltation, "tap me on the shoulder and say, 'Tut! Tut!' and I'll apologize and remedy the defect."

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: "Listen to me, old thing: this is the first time in my life that I've had a real chance to yield to the temptations of a great city. What's the use of a great city having temptations if fellows don't yield to them? Makes it so bally discouraging for a great city. Besides, mother told me to keep my eyes open and collect impressions."

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: I'm a quiet, peaceful sort of chappie who has lived all his life in London, and I can't stand the pace these swift sportsmen from the rural districts set. What I mean to say is this, I'm all for rational enjoyment and so forth, but I think a chappie makes himself conspicuous when he throws soft-boiled eggs at the electric fan.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: The days down on Long Island have forty-eight hours in them; you can't get to sleep at night because of the bellowing of the crickets; and you have to walk two miles for a drink and six for an evening paper.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: She spoke as if she belonged to an anti-sausage society or a league for the suppression of eggs. There was a bit of a silence.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: That's always the way in this world. The chappies you'd like to lend money to won't let you, whereas the chappies you don't want to lend it to will do everything except actually stand you on your head and lift the specie out of your pockets.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: There was a gleam of light when the brother of Bicky's pawnbroker offered ten dollars, money down, for an introduction to old Chiswick, but the deal fell through, owing to its turning out that the chap was an anarchist and intended to kick the old boy instead of shaking hands with him.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: Women with hair and chins like Mary's may be angels most of the time, but, when they take off their wings for a bit, they aren't half-hearted about it.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: I couldn't afford to lose a fellow with his genius for preserving a trouser-crease.

Title: My Man Jeeves (Jeeves & Wooster Series Book 1)
Author: P. G. Wodehouse
Highlight Text: If you come to think of it, what a queer thing Life is! So unlike anything else, don't you know, if you see what I mean. At any moment you may be strolling peacefully along, and all the time Life's waiting around the corner to fetch you one. You can't tell when you may be going to get it. It's all dashed puzzling.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: T. R. says, as we’re leaving after working out, “Nothing you face today will be harder than what you just did.”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Real work and real satisfaction come from the opposite of what the web provides. They come from going deep into something—the book you’re writing, the album, the movie—and staying there for a long, long time.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “God will not have his work made manifest by cowards.”—Ralph Waldo Emerson

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Work becomes fun, and you have energy for days because this life is not a “young man’s game.” It is an “inspired person’s game.” The keys belong to whoever is inspired, and no specific age, sex, gender, or cultural background has a monopoly on inspiration.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Suffering is a moment of clarity, when you can no longer deny the truth of a situation and are forced into uncomfortable change.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Inside suffering is the seed of change.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Make sure I’m dedicating my time to the right people with the question, “Is this someone I might be thinking about when I’m on my deathbed?”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: We discourage failure and by doing so we subtly discourage success.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Science isn’t about being right preemptively or knowing the answer. Science is motivated by the human drive to struggle to discover.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: You will likely be your own worst critic. Be kind to yourself in your own mind. Let your mind show you the same kindness that you aspire to show others.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: People who offer great advice understand that their goal is to help someone on their unique journey. People who offer bad advice are trying to relive their old glories.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: remember what their favorite children’s book was. A book that you read over and over and over again. Somewhere in that book is the clue to not only what makes you tick, but also to your life’s purpose.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Research shows we’re remarkably committed to maintaining a consistent sense of external identity, even if we only established it to begin with out of politeness.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “One does not accumulate but eliminate. It is not daily increase but daily decrease. The height of cultivation always runs to simplicity.” –Bruce Lee Martial artist, actor, and author of Tao of Jeet Kune Do

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “It is vain to do with more what can be done with less.” –William of Ockham English philosopher and originator of Occam’s Razor

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “The difference between winning and losing is most often not quitting.” This famous line from Walt Disney

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Barnacles of the good life tend to slow you down, if you don’t get used to risk-taking early in your career.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “Hard choices, easy life. Easy choices, hard life.”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: day he cornered me and said, “I

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: It encapsulates what art can do—move you, and in such a simple way.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: life is short, and we only have the current moment.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Anybody can talk about why something’s bad. Try doing something good.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: It depends what kind of overwhelming

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “Many a false step was made by standing still.”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: This is precisely the wrong way to face the future. Face it full of hope, knowing that whatever challenge lies ahead, you are equal to it, and just deliver a message that is precisely the opposite of fear and defensiveness.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: listen to my gratitude playlist on Spotify, any song on the list. For example, here are nine tracks as of today: “Breathturn” by Hammock “Your Hand in Mine” by Explosions in the Sky “Devi Prayer” by Craig Pruess and Ananda “Horizon” by Tycho “Recurring” by Bonobo “Hanging On” by Active Child “Long Time Sun” by Snatam Kaur “Angels Prayer” by Ty Burhoe, James Hoskins, Cat McCarthy, Manorama, and Janaki Kagel “Twentytwofourteen” by The Album Leaf

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: The fact is that when two extreme opinions meet, the truth lies generally somewhere in the middle. Without exposure to the other side, you will naturally drift toward the extremes and away from the truth of the matter.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Don’t be afraid of being wrong. Because being wrong is just an opportunity to find more of the truth.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: If you define failure as merely losing, then you will think failure is just an outcome.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Losing makes you think in ways victories can’t. You begin asking questions instead of feeling like you have the answers. Questions open up the doors to so many possibilities.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: First, whenever possible, connect with others. Second, with enthusiasm, strive always to create fun and delight for others. And third, lean into each moment and encounter expecting magic—or miracles.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “Money in a business is like gas in your car. You need to pay attention so you don’t end up on the side of the road. But your trip is not a tour of gas stations.”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: It isn’t technology that eliminates jobs, it is the shortsighted business decisions that use technology simply to cut costs and fatten corporate profits.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: The point of technology isn’t to make money. It’s to solve problems!

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Excellence is the next five minutes or nothing at all. It’s the quality of your next five-minute conversation. It’s the quality of, yes, your next email. Forget the long term. Make the next five minutes rock!

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: feels uncomfortable to spend time and resources trying to figure out exactly what the problem is—we want to jump to fixing way too fast.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Embrace uncertainty, groundlessness, and fear as the place where you’ll really learn and grow. Go into that place, rather than shrinking from it.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: If you continue to optimize your mastery, you’ll eventually arrive at your passion.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: The more you divide your focus, the more each endeavor can suffer from your lack of attention.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “You are a person worthy of love. You don’t have to do anything to prove that. You do not have to earn love. You simply have to exist.”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Professor Michael Merzenich at UCSF has found that neural plasticity does not disappear in adults. It just requires mental exercise. Use it or lose it. Bottom line: Embrace lifelong learning. Do something new. Physical exercise is repetitive; mental exercise is eclectic.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Almost all advice given to writers by supposed experts is wrong. Because almost all of it tells the aspirant to engage in some kind of calculation about marketing before setting out to write. Now, in nonfiction, this may make sense. But that’s not my thing. For artists, the most important thing is total engagement. So I always tell writers to follow their curiosity, obsessions, and fascinations.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Having a mind characterized by ADHD patterns, it’s easy for me to lose focus, to succumb to distraction. The question that helps me return to the present is, simply, “Is what I am doing right now aligned with my life’s calling?” My calling—what lights me up and inspires me the most—is freedom for everyone, including myself: politically, socially, emotionally, and spiritually.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: My advice to entrepreneurs: Once your idea has gained traction, cut the umbilical cord. Your idea can’t take flight if you don’t leave the nest.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: have miles to go before I sleep, and so I will spend my remaining years desperately looking to improve who I am from year to year. Greatness is not a final destination, but a series of small acts done daily in order to constantly rejuvenate and refresh our skills in a daily effort to become a better version of ourselves.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: So the longer-term challenge is simply designing your life so that you have more of this stuff and less of the fluff. Look at every activity as you go through your day and think, “Is this contributing to getting me a better day—today—and if not, is there anybody in the world who has managed to design this activity out of their lives and still succeed beyond my level?”

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Learn Transcendental Meditation as taught by Maharishi Mahesh Yogi and meditate regularly. Ignore pessimistic thinking and pessimistic thinkers.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: When you feel overwhelmed or unfocused, what do you do? I sit and desire ideas.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Everybody is striving after social proof—from a close friend’s adulation to online likes and upvotes. The less you need positive feedback on your ideas, the more original design regions you can explore, and the more creative and, in the long term, useful to society you will be.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World

Highlight Text: If you put ten people in a room and they have to choose an ice cream flavor, they’re gonna arrive at vanilla. There is always constant pressure to conform. But originality only happens on the edges of reality.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Managers need to carefully determine the areas in their business where new technology is the right choice and other areas where a back-to-basics management approach may be more effective.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Top down (macro thinking) means I consider the big-picture issues before the small when making decisions, and these [big-picture] issues dominate my preferences. It does not mean I ignore the small issues, as they are necessary but not dominant. For example, I invest in real estate where smart people want to live. While I could make money in other areas of the country, over the long term, this rule will be quite lucrative.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Life is not designed to hand us success or satisfaction, but rather to present us with challenges that make us grow.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: If your highest goal is incremental, patient, continual learning and development in critical skills and core competencies—and you allow recognition, promotions, and financial rewards to be a natural result of the excellence you attain at core competencies—you will be far more likely to experience success and satisfaction, and perhaps even attain eminence, in your field.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: Join a team not for what it is, but for what you think you can help it become. Be a “founder” in the sense that you’re willing to make something rather than just join something.

Title: Tribe Of Mentors: Short Life Advice from the Best in the World
Author: Timothy Ferriss
Highlight Text: “If I am not for myself, who will be for me? But if I am only for myself, what am I? And if not now, when?” –Rabbi Hillel

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts

Highlight Text: What we believe and what we think about matters, and the enemy knows it. And he is determined to get in your head to distract you from doing good and to sink you so deep that you feel helpless, overwhelmed, shut down, and incapable of rising to make a difference for the kingdom of God.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts
Author: Jennie Allen
Highlight Text: The thing is, I have always believed lies. And not just believed them but built entire chapters of my life around them. I’m pretty sure the same is true for you.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts
Author: Jennie Allen
Highlight Text: Psychiatry 101 teaches therapists that when you and I choose to believe a lie about ourselves, it’s one of these three lies we believe: I’m helpless. I’m worthless. I’m unlovable.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts
Author: Jennie Allen
Highlight Text: Bible study teacher Beth Moore, a self-described “former pit-dweller,” has said that there are three kinds of pits: the kind we jump into, the kind we accidentally slip into, and the kind we’re thrown into.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts

Highlight Text: Doubt steals hope. And with no hope, everything that matters doesn’t feel as important anymore.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts

Highlight Text: Because alone in the dark the devil can tell you whatever the hell he wants.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts
Author: Jennie Allen
Highlight Text: You have a God-given, God-empowered, God-redeemed ability to choose what you think about. You have a choice regarding where you focus your energy. You have a choice regarding what you live for. I have a choice.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts
Author: Jennie Allen
Highlight Text: What we think about, our brains become. What we fixate on is neurologically who we will be.

Title: Get Out of Your Head: Stopping the Spiral of Toxic Thoughts
Author: Jennie Allen
Highlight Text: Bondage necessitates rescue. Oppression needs to be lifted. Blindness waits for sight. Waywardness must be transformed.
